data.title: Polycom eyes India acquisitions, earmarks $300 m for inorganic growth
data.text:
HYDERABAD: Nasdaq-listed Polycom, a leading unified collaborative communications solutions provider, is looking at acquisitions in India to help enhance its technology solutions or market access. The company has earmarked $300 million to fund its inorganic growth plans.

“We are yet to finalise our acquisition targets here as inorganic growth is part of our global business strategy. India is a growing market for our products and technologies and an acquisition will help us accelerate growth here. We are also looking at other geographies including Europe and the US for acquisitions,” said senior V-P & general manager (voice division) Sunil K Bhalla.

Last year, the company had earmarked around $500 million for acquisitions. It acquired SpectraLink in North America for $220 million.

The company is also stepping up its investment in India and increasing its penetration here. As part of this strategy, it has set up an R&D centre in Hyderabad at an investment of $5 million. The centre has about 70 engineers now and the plan is to raise it to over 100 as the facility can accommodate 160 engineers, said Mr Bhalla.

The Hyderabad R&D centre will focus on developing patentable technologies for the company’s voice communication solutions for mobile, desktop and conferencing applications. The centre will also work along with Microsoft for building unified communication devices.

Polycom has marketing and sales offices in Delhi, Mumbai , Bangalore and Hyderabad and would soon open offices in Chennai and Kolkata. “We are also entering tier II cities and will open offices in Pune, Ahmedabad, Bhopal and Chandigarh next year. This will help us get closer to the growing markets in these places. Besides, our existing customers in India including KPOs and BPOs are also expanding to small cities,’’ said Polycom regional director (India & South Asia) Yugal Sharma.
